sentence_left: The Battle of Wau, 29–31 January 1943, was a battle in the New Guinea campaign of World War II.
sentence_right: Forces of the Empire of Japan sailed from Rabaul and crossed the Solomon Sea and, despite Allied air attacks, successfully reached Lae, where they disembarked.
label: False

sentence_left: Forces of the Empire of Japan sailed from Rabaul and crossed the Solomon Sea and, despite Allied air attacks, successfully reached Lae, where they disembarked.
sentence_right: Japanese troops then advanced overland on Wau, an Australian base that potentially threatened the Japanese positions at Salamaua and Lae.
label: False

sentence_left: Japanese troops then advanced overland on Wau, an Australian base that potentially threatened the Japanese positions at Salamaua and Lae.
sentence_right: A race developed between the Japanese moving overland, hampered by the terrain, and the Australians, moving by air, hampered by the weather.
label: False

sentence_left: A race developed between the Japanese moving overland, hampered by the terrain, and the Australians, moving by air, hampered by the weather.
sentence_right: By the time the Japanese reached the Wau area after a trek over the mountains, the Australian defenders had been greatly reinforced by air.
label: False

sentence_left: By the time the Japanese reached the Wau area after a trek over the mountains, the Australian defenders had been greatly reinforced by air.
sentence_right: In the battle that followed, despite achieving tactical surprise by approaching from an unexpected direction, the Japanese attackers were unable to capture Wau.
label: True

sentence_left: Wau is a town in New Guinea, in the province of Morobe situated at one end of the Wau-Bulolo Valley.
sentence_right: It was the site of a gold rush during the 1920s and 1930s.
label: False

sentence_left: It was the site of a gold rush during the 1920s and 1930s.
sentence_right: Gold prospectors arrived at the coast at Salamaua and struggled inland along the Black Cat Track.

sentence_right: The miners partially cleared the area and built houses and workshops, and established a water supply and an electricity grid.

sentence_right: They constructed the aerodromes at Wau and Bulolo which were the primary means of reaching the Wau-Bulolo Valley.
label: False

sentence_left: They constructed the aerodromes at Wau and Bulolo which were the primary means of reaching the Wau-Bulolo Valley.
sentence_right: Wau aerodrome was a rough Kunai grass airstrip in length with a 10 per cent slope heading directly for Mount Kaindi.
label: False

sentence_left: Wau aerodrome was a rough Kunai grass airstrip in length with a 10 per cent slope heading directly for Mount Kaindi.
sentence_right: Aircraft could approach from the north east only, landing uphill and taking off downhill.
label: False

sentence_left: Aircraft could approach from the north east only, landing uphill and taking off downhill.

sentence_right: This required good visibility, but the weather over Owen Stanley Range was characterised by frequent storms, vertical drafts, and mists which rose from the jungle floor.

sentence_left: After the war with Japan began, Wau became an evacuation centre, receiving refugees from Lae and Salamaua.

sentence_left: Non-native women and children were evacuated while men of military age were called up for service in the New Guinea Volunteer Rifles, the local militia unit.
sentence_right: Initially, civilians were evacuated by civilian aircraft but as the Japanese drew closer—bombing Wau on 23 January 1942—it became too dangerous to fly without fighter escort, which was unavailable.
